destinations.description: Only Coordinates Coordinates for an area in deep space.
Hostile Forest/Jungle/Desert Landing site is planet-side wilderness, far from human habitation, or on an uninhabited world.
Mine A mining facility, far from a colony or starport.
Spaceport Spaceport on an asteroid or moon, or a landing field near a larger settlement.
Asteroid/Moon The surface of an asteroid or a small moon. Vacuum or dangerous atmosphere.
Space Station An orbiting space station.
Earth The busy hub of all interstellar traffic and commerce.
Young Colony A small colony with only a few hundred inhabitants.
Established Colony A busy colony with several thousand people and a thriving, local industry.
Starship A starship in orbit, awaiting your arrival.
Outpost A small outpost, usually planetside. An outpost is commonly just a single complex with a specific function; corporate, military or scientific.

goods.description: Propylene, acetylene, propane, ethyl-formate, chlorofluorocarbon, ammonia, carbon monoxide, ethylene oxide, hydrogen chloride, sulfur dioxide, sulfur hexafluoride.
Gold, platinum, palladium, silver, tungsten, copper, iron, etc.
Humans in stasis, ready to begin a colonization project
Exotic alien tree products destined for Earth
Water, water ice or some other rare frozen solution

Aluminium Chloride, Aluminium Sulfate, Calcium Acetate, Monosodium Phosphate, Ferric Sulphate, Sodium Hydroxide, Hydrochloric Acid, Sodium Aluminate, Polyaluminium Chloride, Ferrous Chloride, Borate, Potassium Acetate etc.
Multi-nutrient fertilizer compounds made up of nitrogen, potassium and/or phosphate
Crude oil, or liquid petroleum by-products
Bulk foods such as chickpeas, soybeans and other legumes, grains (corn, barley, rice, wheat) or refined versions thereof
Bauxite (aluminum), galena (lead), pentlandite (nickel), gold-quartz, cassiterite (tin), malachite (copper), magnetite (iron), platinum-bearing sand, trimonite (tungsten)
Vaccines, medicines, disinfectants, surgical gear, scanning machines, hospital beds
Different makes and types, for suits, refineries, vehicles, power stations, hospitals, prospecting gear, factories, atmospheric processors, weaponry or life support systems
Modules, features, parts for/from dismantled ships
Space suits for delivery to the colonies
Wind turbines, power station generator, space station hull frame, solar panel assembly, drilling machinery, ore processing mill or furnace
Diggers, tractors, quad-tracks, all-terrain vehicles, power loaders
Firearms, ammunition and armor for the colonies or remote stations
Processed uranium cakes or uranium dioxide powder, or fusion plant fuel pellets such as deuterium, tritium, protium or helium-3
Beams, modules, airlocks, outer shells, roofing material, etc.
Feed concentrates containing grains, high-protein oil meals and byproducts of sugar beet and sugarcane processing
Cattle in stasis, ready for rearing on an off-world colony
Shuttle, or escape/cargo pod requiring investigation and study

complications.description: The destination is placed under quarantine or an embargo.
The ship’s computer brings the ship out of hyperspace early, and then wakes the crew. What’s the story?
A military starship sends over a small search party for a “routine” ICC and customs check. Should the PCs be worried?

There is a delay in lift-off/undocking; perhaps fuel for the reaction drives or coolant cannot be pumped aboard. There may be a strike, an administrative hold-up or loading equipment may have broken down.

A critical part (drive pump, plasma coil, coolant pump, water recycler, gravity compensator control unit, sensor gimbal motor, etc.) requires replacement before it fails, requiring most of the crew’s participation.
Problems at the destination mean they aren’t ready to accept the cargo. Can the crew help speed things along?
There is a serious problem with the cargo, either moving, leaking, over-heating or catching fire.
A small piece of wreckage is spotted on the sensor scope; a cargo container, escape pod, frozen corpse, part of a starship—smashed or blown off, etc.

missions.description: Scout a location, gather intelligence and then report back.
Attack and hold an objective by force.
Defend a location/person/group and repel any attack until relieved or until a set time.
Patrol Patrol an area, looking for signs of the enemy.
Infiltrate an enemy location and destroy a key asset (bridge, uplink tower, radar dish, etc.)
Create chaos and destruction by attacking targets of opportunity behind enemy lines.
Search for a downed pilot, lost colonists, etc.
Quell a riot and re-establishing order, or protect lines of communication and essential services until authority can be restored.
Exterminate local alien life that is threatening colonists on an off-world planet.
A colonial or space station population needs immediate rescue from a crisis or natural catastrophe.
A space station, orbital platform or starship must be captured (or recaptured) by boarding it and seizing control.
The marines are aboard a military vessel that makes customs and security checks on civilian ships in the area, looking for illegal drugs or other goods, arms, workers being trafficked etc.
Locate and seize an item, person or group from behind enemy lines. It may be hostages, POWs, an enemy commander or a piece of high technology.
A station, colony or installation is not responding to Network communications. Investigate.

objectives.description: Either an established or young colony.
A research station or remote military outpost.
An enemy ship, or perhaps an abandoned ship.
A transfer station, space colony or orbital survey platform.
Far from civilization, a remote spot on a planetary surface.
An active war zone, fought between colonies, corporations or nation states, with ruined buildings, wrecked vehicles and fortifications.
A landing field far from any colony, owned by a corporation, individual or military.
Colonial farmsteads, far from civilization and scattered across the planetary surface.
A huge mining and refining complex, with hundreds of workers and executives.
Remote penal colony, housing hardened and violent inmates.
An automated sensor site, perhaps with its own defenses.
Harsh, inhospitable wilderness such as thick jungle, deep caverns or volcanic lava fields.

complications.description: The marines find out that the bad guys are actually good guys.
During the mission, the marines may find themselves saddled with enemy prisoners or innocent civilians that they must now guard/protect.
The team is saddled with a reporter/cameraman or a senior officer who gets in the way and asks stupid questions.
A corporate representative joins the team and is there to ensure the company’s assets and interests are protected.
Technical knowledge or on-site advice is provided by a civilian advisor who has little knowledge of military operations. They may get scared or panic easily.
An NPC or even a PC is captured by hostile forces.
The team has faulty gear. It could be anything from ammo or weapons to sensors or vehicles.
The opponents are far tougher and more ruthless than expected.
During the mission, the team discovers that it is completely trapped, either physically, or tactically.
The mission location is hit by an air-strike, mines, or heavy weapons, possibly the result of a mishap by their own forces!
A new commanding office, a lieutenant, is keen to get himself a medal or commendation, and pushes the marine squad into perilous situations. Someone is going to get killed!
There are hidden dangers across the mission site, varying with the nature of the location. They may be mines, IEDs, predatory carnivorous plants or improvised booby traps.
There are tactical restrictions placed on the mission—how the squad acts, where it can go, what weapons it can use, etc.
Commander A new platoon commander is a green, untested and untried lieutenant. He’s read the books, survived the training and ran the simulations—but he’ll go to pieces once the bullets start flying.
